docs.title: Group 7 Project Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the official documentation site for Group 7 of the DS223 – Marketing Analytics course. This site includes our Problem Definition, Methodology, Implementation Plan, and other project-related resources.

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
Our project focuses on developing a dynamic pricing and product testing system using Thompson Sampling, a multi-armed bandit (MAB) algorithm. The goal is to help businesses identify the optimal price point for a product faster, more efficiently, and more adaptively than traditional A/B testing.

This documentation covers:

  • Problem Area & Motivation
  • Preliminary Research
  • Methodology
  • Data Collection & Algorithms
  • Expected Outcomes
  • Evaluation Metrics

For the full description, visit: - Problem Definition

docs.title: Documentation Pages
docs.text:
• Problem Definition
  • Additional sections (Methodology, Implementation, Results) will be added as the project progresses.

docs.title: Project Goal
docs.text: Build an adaptive, data-driven pricing experimentation platform that helps companies optimize product pricing using real-time customer behavior and probabilistic learning algorithms.

docs.title: How to Use This Documentation
docs.text:
Use the navigation panel on the left to browse all project sections. Each page will be updated as our team progresses through development, experimentation, and analysis.

This documentation website is maintained by Group 7.

docs.title: API Documentation — Smart Pricing Playground
docs.text:
This document describes all API endpoints used in the Smart Pricing Playground system. The API acts as the backend communication layer between the frontend, database, ETL pipeline, and Thompson Sampling engine.

The endpoints support: - Product & experiment creation - Bandit setup and configuration - Price selection via Thompson Sampling - Event logging (impressions, conversions, revenue) - Performance and analytics retrieval

docs.title: 1. Base URL
docs.text: For local development:

docs.title: Admin App Documentation — Smart Pricing Playground
docs.text:
The Admin App is the main interface for marketers and product managers. It allows users to create pricing experiments, configure price variants, monitor performance, and view analytics generated by Thompson Sampling.

This page describes the structure, functionality, and user flow of the admin application.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
The Admin App provides:

  • Product management
  • Price variant configuration
  • Bandit (experiment) setup
  • Real-time analytics
  • Posterior distribution visualizations
  • Experiment summary dashboards

The interface is implemented using Streamlit, backed by the Smart Pricing Playground API.

docs.title: 2. Main App Sections
docs.text:
The Admin UI is divided into the following pages:

  1. Dashboard / Home — lists projects and experiments
  2. Create Product — upload product info and image
  3. Define Price Variants — configure bandit arms
  4. Experiment View — run pricing experiments
  5. Analytics — performance tables and charts
  6. Posterior Visualization — Thompson Sampling distributions

docs.title: Step 1 — Create a Product
docs.text:
Users provide: - Product name - Description - Optional image upload

Once created, the product receives a project_id.

docs.title: Step 2 — Add Price Variants
docs.text:
Each price variant becomes a bandit arm.

A price variant includes: - Price - Initial parameters (mean, variance or alpha, beta) - Label (optional)

The UI performs validation before sending data to the backend.

docs.title: Step 3 — Launch the Experiment
docs.text:
After prices are created, users can:

  • View the current active experiment
  • Trigger price selection
  • Monitor incoming interactions
  • Reset or restart experiments

The UI pulls updated bandit metrics every time data changes.

docs.title: 4.1 Product Card
docs.text:
Displays:

  • Image
  • Name
  • Description
  • Button to manage price variants

docs.title: 4.2 Price Variant Table
docs.text:
Shows real-time metrics:

Price Impressions Conversions Conversion Rate Mean Reward

Updated automatically via API calls.

docs.title: 4.3 Posterior Distribution Plot
docs.text:
Graphs the probability density for each price. Shows how the algorithm updates beliefs based on live data.

Displayed using backend-generated image or Streamlit chart.

docs.title: 5. Integration with Thompson Sampling
docs.text: The Admin App interacts with:

docs.title: POST /projects/{id}/thompson/select
docs.text: Used to trigger the next price selection whenever an experiment runs.

docs.title: GET /projects/{id}/posterior
docs.text: Used to update the graph after each iteration.

docs.title: GET /projects/{id}/bandits/performance
docs.text: Used to populate analytics and summary tables.

docs.title: 6. Analytics Dashboard
docs.text: The dashboard displays:

docs.title: KPIs
docs.text:
• Total impressions
  • Total conversions
  • Overall revenue
  • Estimated optimal price

docs.title: Charts
docs.text:
• Conversion rate per price
  • Revenue distribution
  • Time-series experiment performance
  • Posterior distributions

docs.title: Tables
docs.text: • Aggregations used for evaluation (mean, variance, trials)

docs.title: 7. Design Philosophy
docs.text:
The Admin App is designed to be:

  • Simple for non-technical users
  • Interpretable through clear analytics
  • Extensible for new algorithms
  • Modular through well-separated API calls

docs.title: 8. Summary
docs.text:
The Admin App is the control center for Smart Pricing Playground. It:

  • Manages experiments
  • Displays real-time analytics
  • Visualizes Thompson Sampling learning
  • Enables intuitive, data-driven pricing decisions

The app connects seamlessly to the backend and ETL pipeline, ensuring that experimentation is both accessible and scientifically grounded.

docs.title: Demo: Smart Pricing Playground
docs.text: This page provides an overview of how the Smart Pricing Playground works from a user’s perspective. It demonstrates the main workflow for creating experiments, assigning prices, collecting data, and viewing real-time analytics.

docs.title: 1. Overview of the Demo
docs.text:
The demo showcases how marketers or product managers can:

  • Upload a product
  • Define price variants
  • Launch a pricing experiment
  • Automatically allocate traffic using Thompson Sampling
  • Review real-time analytics
  • Identify the optimal price efficiently

The system is fully automated and does not require statistical expertise.

docs.title: Step 1 — Upload or Select a Product
docs.text:
Users begin by creating a new product or selecting an existing one.

Uploaded metadata includes: - Product name - Description - Image - Price options

Example: - Product: "Wireless Fitness Tracker" - Price Variants: $29, $39, $49

docs.title: Step 2 — Define Price Variants
docs.text:
The user specifies all price points they want to test.

The platform allows: - Any number of price options - Either even or custom initial distribution - Optional per-variant description or label

The system initializes a bandit agent for each price.

docs.title: Step 3 — Launch the Experiment
docs.text:
Once price variants are saved, the experiment becomes active.

The system starts: - Tracking impressions - Tracking conversions (purchase / click) - Logging revenue events - Updating posterior probability distributions for each price arm

This marks the start of adaptive learning.

docs.title: Step 4 — Real-Time Visitor Interactions
docs.text:
Visitors land on the demo product page and see a single price option.

  • The first several visitors are shown random prices
  • As data accumulates, Thompson Sampling begins prioritizing strong performers
  • Low-performing prices automatically receive less traffic

The system records: - Which price the visitor saw - Whether they converted - How much revenue was generated

docs.title: Step 5 — Thompson Sampling in Action
docs.text:
As soon as conversions begin, the learning loop runs:

  1. For each price, sample from its posterior distribution
  2. Select the price with the highest sampled value
  3. Serve this price to the next user
  4. Update posteriors after each interaction

This ensures: - Faster convergence to the optimal price - Lower regret - More efficient experimentation

docs.title: Product Display
docs.text: Shows: - Product name - Product image - Descrip

docs.title: Core Pipeline for Smart Pricing Playground
docs.text: This document describes the end-to-end Core Pipeline used to collect user interaction data, validate and structure it, and prepare it for pricing analytics within the Smart Pricing Playground platform. The pipeline ensures that data used for Thompson Sampling and performance analysis is accurate, consistent, and updated continuously.

docs.title: 1. Overview of the Core Pipeline
docs.text:
The Core Pipeline supports the adaptive pricing engine by:

  • Collecting real-time interaction data
  • Validating and cleaning incoming events
  • Transforming raw events into structured analytical datasets
  • Computing metrics required by Thompson Sampling
  • Storing final outputs for access by the API and dashboard

This workflow runs continuously as user activity takes place.

docs.title: 2.1 Sources of Data
docs.text:
Data is collected from:

  • Frontend interaction events

  • Impressions

  • Conversions
  • Revenue events

  • Metadata (device, timestamp, session)

  • Backend API events

  • Price selection logs

  • Experiment lifecycle events
  • Bandit updates

docs.title: 2.2 Event Capture Logic
docs.text:
When a user interacts with a pricing experiment, the frontend sends events such as:

  • impression_event
  • conversion_event
  • revenue_event

Each event includes:

  • Experiment ID
  • Price/Bandit ID
  • Timestamp
  • Session or user identifier
  • Outcome details (click, purchase, revenue)

Raw events are stored in a designated staging layer.

docs.title: 3.1 Cleaning and Validation
docs.text:
The pipeline performs:

  • Removal of malformed records
  • Validation of experiment and price IDs
  • Type enforcement (numeric, boolean, timestamp)
  • Deduplication of impressions within a session
  • Revenue normalization

docs.title: 3.2 Feature Construction
docs.text: Metrics required for Thompson Sampling are computed:

docs.title: Bernoulli conversion model
docs.text:
• trials = impressions
  • successes = conversions
  • failures = trials – successes

docs.title: Gaussian revenue model
docs.text:
• n = count of revenue observations
  • mean = average revenue
  • variance = observed reward variance

docs.title: 3.3 Aggregation
docs.text:
Data is aggregated per:

  • Experiment
  • Price arm
  • Optional time windows

Example output

price_id impressions conversions conversion_rate mean_reward variance 1 120 18 0.15 3.20 1.4 2 115 26 0.23 3.85 1.1

docs.title: 3.4 Thompson Sampling Parameters
docs.text:
For each price arm:

Bernoulli TS

  • α = successes + 1
  • β = failures + 1

Gaussian TS

  • μ = sample mean
  • σ² = sample variance
  • n = observation count

These parameters form the priors/posteriors used for price selection.

docs.title: 4.1 Database Structures
docs.text:
Processed data is stored in:

  • experiments
  • bandits
  • impressions
  • conversions
  • aggregates
  • posterior_parameters

These tables feed the algorithm, dashboard, and analytics API.

docs.title: 4.2 API Integration
docs.text:
Stored outputs are used by endpoints such as:

  • /bandits/select – computes the next price via Thompson Sampling
  • /bandits/performance – returns experiment metrics
  • /bandits/posterior – returns posterior distributions

docs.title: 4.3 Dashboard Integration
docs.text:
The dashboard uses refined data to show:

  • Conversion and revenue performance
  • Price-arm comparisons
  • Posterior distribution graphs
  • Experiment progress in real time

docs.title: 5. Core Pipeline Summary
docs.text:
1. Data Collection Capture user interactions and store raw records.

  2. Data Refinement Clean, validate, structure, and aggregate data. Compute Thompson Sampling parameters.

  3. Data Storage & Delivery Persist processed datasets. Power API endpoints and dashboards.

docs.title: 6. Importance of the Core Pipeline
docs.text:
Accurate adaptive pricing requires a reliable data pipeline. A strong Core Pipeline provides:

  • Reliable conversion and revenue metrics
  • Fast updates for real-time learning
  • High-quality analytics for business insights
  • Scalability for larger experiments

The Core Pipeline is therefore a foundational component of the Smart Pricing Playground system.
